What Is Mental Wellbeing?

Mental wellbeing is often used to describe our current mental state
and how well we feel we are coping with everday life and stress.
Good mental wellbing means we are able to cope better when faced
with conflict or distressing events.

Intense traumatic events at any stage of life can affect our
mental wellbeing, for example times of intense grief at the loss
of a loved one or a serious or frightening accident on the road or elsewhere.

Our mental wellbeing can be impacted when at school especially,
when as a child we have not yet developed the necessary skills to deal
with conflict or stress and this can then have an impact on future relationships
and how we treat ourselves and others.

There are of course ways to improve our mental wellbeing and recently
there has been more in the media highlighting mental health issues
and workplaces have started to embrace a wellbeing programmes,
giving employees options and help on how to deal with worries, stress,
grief or any other issues that may be interefering with everyday life.
This has led to charities like Mind more of a voice in the community.

When people are more aware of their mental state day to day,
they then can learn techniques to overcome adversity.
This is one of the main reasons we started this website,
in order to raise awareness of mental wellbeing and to allow you
to take control of your mental health.

Explore our website to find tips and practical tools to help you improve
your mental wellbeing. On our resources pages you find general or more specific
support through mental health charities, and there are links to other websites
that cover various topics including maintaining good sleep routines,
information on nutrition anxiety coping strategies and many more.
